tech-resume-that-works.title: The Tech Resume That Actually Works
tech-resume-that-works.intro: Your resume has about 6 seconds to make an impression. In a world where recruiters are flooded with applications, you need a document that immediately communicates your value. Let's break down exactly what makes a tech resume work in 2026.

sections.heading: The One-Page Rule
sections.content:
Unless you have 10+ years of experience, your resume should be **one page**. Period.

I know you want to include every project, every skill, every certification. But here's the truth: recruiters don't read resumes—they scan them. A dense, multi-page resume doesn't show thoroughness; it shows you don't know how to prioritize.

**What to include:**
- Contact information (email, phone, LinkedIn, GitHub)
- A brief professional summary (2-3 lines max)
- Work experience (most recent 3-4 positions)
- Education
- Technical skills

**What to leave out:**
- Objective statements (they're outdated)
- Soft skills lists ("team player," "hard worker")
- Every technology you've ever touched
- References ("available upon request" is implied)

sections.heading: The Format That Gets Interviews
sections.content:
Use a clean, simple format. No graphics, no columns, no fancy fonts. Why? Because most large companies use Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) that can't read complex formatting.

**Recommended structure:**

```
[YOUR NAME]
[Email] | [Phone] | [LinkedIn URL] | [GitHub URL] | [City, State]

PROFESSIONAL SUMMARY
[2-3 sentences about who you are and what you bring]

EXPERIENCE
[Company Name] — [Title]
[Date Range]
• [Achievement bullet]
• [Achievement bullet]
• [Achievement bullet]

EDUCATION
[Degree], [School] — [Year]

SKILLS
[Categorized technical skills]
```

**Font choices:** Stick with Arial, Calibri, or Helvetica at 10-11pt. Your name can be 14-16pt.

sections.heading: Writing Bullet Points That Matter
sections.content:
This is where most resumes fail. People list responsibilities instead of achievements. Recruiters don't care what you were supposed to do—they care what you actually accomplished.

**The formula:** Action Verb + What You Did + Result/Impact

**Bad example:**
> Responsible for maintaining the company website

**Good example:**
> Reduced page load time by 40% by implementing lazy loading and image optimization, improving user engagement metrics by 25%

**Power verbs for tech resumes:**
- Built, Developed, Engineered, Architected
- Optimized, Improved, Enhanced, Streamlined
- Led, Managed, Mentored, Coordinated
- Migrated, Integrated, Automated, Deployed
- Reduced, Increased, Saved, Generated

Every bullet should answer: "So what? Why does this matter?"

sections.heading: The Skills Section Done Right
sections.content:
Your skills section should be a quick reference, not a laundry list. Organize it by category and only include technologies you can actually discuss in an interview.

**Example layout:**

```
SKILLS
Languages: Python, JavaScript, TypeScript, SQL
Frameworks: React, Node.js, Django, FastAPI
Cloud & DevOps: AWS (EC2, S3, Lambda), Docker, Kubernetes, CI/CD
Databases: PostgreSQL, MongoDB, Redis
Tools: Git, Jira, Figma
```

**Pro tips:**
- List languages and frameworks first—these are what recruiters search for
- Don't include basic tools everyone knows (Microsoft Office, Google Docs)
- If you list it, be prepared to answer questions about it
- Update this section for each application to match the job description

sections.heading: Projects Section: Your Secret Weapon
sections.content:
If you're early in your career or switching into tech, projects can be more valuable than work experience. But not all projects are created equal.

**What makes a project impressive:**
- It solves a real problem (not just a tutorial follow-along)
- It's deployed and accessible
- It demonstrates relevant technologies
- It shows progression and learning

**Project bullet format:**

```
[Project Name] | [Technologies Used] | [Link]
• [What it does and why it exists]
• [Technical challenge you overcame]
• [Metrics or results if applicable]
```

**Example:**
```
BudgetBuddy | React, Node.js, PostgreSQL | github.com/you/budgetbuddy
• Built a full-stack expense tracking app with real-time sync across devices
• Implemented OAuth 2.0 authentication and bank API integration
• Serves 500+ monthly active users with 99.9% uptime
```

sections.heading: Common Mistakes to Avoid
sections.content:
I've reviewed hundreds of resumes. These mistakes come up again and again:

**1. Typos and grammatical errors**
One typo can get your resume rejected. Use Grammarly, read it backwards, have someone else review it.

**2. Generic descriptions**
"Worked on various projects" tells me nothing. Be specific about what you did.

**3. Including everything**
That summer job at the ice cream shop? Probably not relevant unless you're highlighting customer service for a client-facing role.

**4. Lying or exaggerating**
Don't list technologies you've never used. Technical interviews will expose this immediately, and it's a fast way to get blacklisted.

**5. Using the same resume for every application**
Tailor your resume for each role. Move relevant experience to the top. Mirror keywords from the job description.

**6. Forgetting the human element**
Yes, you need to pass the ATS. But a human will also read this. Make it scannable, make it interesting, make it clear why you're the right fit.

resources.title: Resume Worded
resources.description: AI-powered resume analyzer that scores your resume and suggests improvements

resources.title: Jake's Resume Template
resources.description: Clean, ATS-friendly LaTeX resume template popular in tech

resources.title: Google Technical Resume Guide
resources.description: Official guidance on what Google looks for in technical resumes

keyTakeaways: Keep your resume to one page unless you have 10+ years of experience
Use a simple, ATS-friendly format without graphics or complex layouts
Write achievement-focused bullets using the formula: Action + What + Result
Organize skills by category and only include technologies you can discuss confidently
Tailor your resume for each application by mirroring job description keywords

beating-the-ats.title: Beating the ATS
beating-the-ats.intro: Before a human ever sees your resume, it passes through an Applicant Tracking System. These systems are designed to filter candidates, and if you don't play by their rules, your resume ends up in the digital void. Here's how to beat the algorithm.

sections.heading: How ATS Actually Works
sections.content:
Applicant Tracking Systems are software that companies use to manage job applications. They parse your resume, extract information, and score candidates based on keyword matching and other criteria.

**What the ATS does:**
- Parses your resume into structured data (name, email, work history, skills)
- Searches for keywords that match the job description
- Ranks candidates based on match percentage
- Filters out resumes that don't meet minimum criteria

**The reality:**
- 75% of resumes never reach human eyes
- Many qualified candidates are filtered out due to formatting issues
- The ATS isn't smart—it's looking for exact or near-exact keyword matches

> "The ATS doesn't care how talented you are. It cares whether your resume contains the right words in a format it can read."

sections.heading: Keywords: The Foundation of ATS Success
sections.content:
Keywords are the single most important factor in getting past the ATS. You need to match the language used in the job description.

**How to identify keywords:**
1. Read the job description carefully
2. Highlight technical skills, tools, and technologies mentioned
3. Note soft skills and qualifications that appear multiple times
4. Look at the "requirements" and "nice to have" sections

**Example job description excerpt:**
> Looking for a Software Engineer with experience in Python, Django, and PostgreSQL. Experience with AWS services (EC2, S3, Lambda) preferred. Must have strong problem-solving skills and experience with Agile methodologies.

**Keywords to include:**
- Python, Django, PostgreSQL (exact matches)
- AWS, EC2, S3, Lambda (exact matches)
- Software Engineer (in your title or summary)
- Agile (somewhere in experience section)

**Pro tip:** Use both acronyms and full names. Write "Amazon Web Services (AWS)" the first time, then use AWS throughout.

sections.heading: Formatting Rules for ATS
sections.content:
Many ATS systems struggle with complex formatting. Follow these rules to ensure your resume is parsed correctly:

**Do:**
- Use standard section headings (Experience, Education, Skills)
- Stick to .docx or .pdf format (check the application instructions)
- Use bullet points (• or -) for lists
- Include dates in a standard format (MM/YYYY or Month YYYY)
- Put your name at the top

**Don't:**
- Use tables or columns (ATS may read them out of order)
- Include images, graphics, or icons
- Use headers or footers (some ATS skip these)
- Use text boxes
- Get creative with section names ("Where I've Made an Impact" instead of "Experience")

**Testing your format:**
Copy your resume text into a plain text editor (Notepad). If it's readable and in order, the ATS can probably parse it.

sections.heading: The Keyword Placement Strategy
sections.content:
It's not just about having keywords—it's about where you put them.

**High-impact placement areas:**

1. **Professional Summary** — Include 3-5 key technologies and your job title
2. **Job Titles** — Match your title to the role (if accurate)
3. **Skills Section** — Comprehensive list of technical keywords
4. **Experience Bullets** — Naturally incorporate tools and technologies

**Example summary optimized for ATS:**

> Software Engineer with 4 years of experience building scalable web applications using Python, Django, and React. Expertise in cloud infrastructure (AWS), database design (PostgreSQL, MongoDB), and Agile development practices. Track record of reducing system latency and improving application performance.

**Keyword density matters:**
If a job mentions Python 5 times, you should mention it at least 2-3 times throughout your resume. But don't keyword stuff—every mention should be natural and contextual.

sections.heading: Common ATS Killers
sections.content:
These formatting choices will tank your ATS score:

**1. Creative file formats**
Stick to .docx or .pdf. Never submit a .pages, .jpg, or Google Doc link.

**2. Non-standard fonts**
Use Arial, Calibri, Times New Roman, or Helvetica. Fancy fonts may not render correctly.

**3. Spelling variations**
The ATS doesn't know that "Javascript" and "JavaScript" are the same thing. Use the exact spelling from the job description.

**4. Abbreviations without context**
Always write out the full term at least once: "Search Engine Optimization (SEO)"

**5. Information in the wrong sections**
Don't put skills in your education section or work experience in a "Projects" section if the ATS expects a standard format.

**6. Missing contact information**
Some ATS systems require a valid email and phone number to process your application.

sections.heading: Testing and Optimizing
sections.content:
Before submitting, test your resume against the job description.

**Manual check:**
1. Print the job description
2. Highlight every technical skill, tool, and qualification mentioned
3. Check that each highlighted item appears somewhere in your resume
4. If something is missing and you have the skill, add it

**Tools to help:**
- **Jobscan** — Compares your resume to job descriptions and gives a match score
- **Resume Worded** — AI-powered analysis with specific improvement suggestions
- **ATS Resume Checker** — Tests if your resume can be parsed correctly

**Target score:** Aim for 70%+ keyword match with the job description. Below 60%, you're likely to be filtered out.

**Remember:** ATS optimization is necessary, but it's not sufficient. Once you pass the ATS, a human still needs to be impressed. Balance keyword optimization with compelling, readable content.

resources.title: Jobscan
resources.description: Compare your resume against job descriptions and get a match percentage

resources.title: ATS Resume Test
resources.description: Free resume review that shows how ATS systems see your resume

resources.title: Most Common ATS Systems
resources.description: Understanding the most popular ATS platforms companies use

keyTakeaways: 75% of resumes are filtered out by ATS before a human sees them
Extract keywords directly from job descriptions and include them naturally
Use simple formatting—no tables, graphics, or creative section headings
Write out acronyms fully at least once (e.g., Amazon Web Services (AWS))
Test your resume with tools like Jobscan and aim for 70%+ match

quantifying-your-impact.title: Quantifying Your Impact
quantifying-your-impact.intro: Numbers are the language of impact. A resume that says 'improved performance' tells me nothing. A resume that says 'reduced API response time by 65%, handling 2M daily requests' tells me everything. Let's turn your experience into measurable achievements.

sections.heading: Why Numbers Matter
sections.content:
Recruiters and hiring managers see hundreds of resumes with vague claims like "improved efficiency" or "enhanced user experience." Numbers cut through the noise and provide proof.

**The psychology of numbers:**
- They're specific, which implies accuracy and honesty
- They're memorable (you'll stand out)
- They demonstrate business awareness
- They give interviewers something concrete to discuss

**Compare these bullets:**

❌ "Improved application performance"

✅ "Reduced page load time from 4.2s to 1.8s (57% improvement), increasing user session duration by 23%"

The second bullet tells a story. It shows you measured before, implemented a solution, and measured after. That's the mindset companies want to hire.

sections.heading: What to Measure
sections.content:
Almost any work can be quantified. Here are the categories to think about:

**Performance metrics:**
- Response times, load times, latency
- Throughput (requests per second, transactions processed)
- Uptime and reliability (99.9% availability)
- Error rates (reduced errors by X%)

**Scale metrics:**
- Users served (daily/monthly active users)
- Data processed (TBs of data, millions of records)
- Traffic handled (requests per day)
- Geographic reach (deployed across X regions)

**Business metrics:**
- Revenue impact (generated $X, increased sales by Y%)
- Cost savings (reduced infrastructure costs by $X/month)
- Time savings (automated process saving X hours/week)
- Customer satisfaction (improved NPS by X points)

**Team and process metrics:**
- Team size managed
- Sprint velocity improvements
- Code review turnaround time
- Deployment frequency

sections.heading: The STAR-Q Method
sections.content:
Take the classic STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result) and add Q for Quantification.

**Framework:**
- **Situation:** What was the context?
- **Task:** What needed to be done?
- **Action:** What did you specifically do?
- **Result:** What happened?
- **Quantification:** What numbers prove it?

**Example transformation:**

**Before (no quantification):**
> Built a notification system for the mobile app

**After (STAR-Q applied):**
> Architected and deployed a real-time notification system using WebSockets and Redis, enabling instant alerts for 850K users across iOS and Android, reducing notification delivery time from 30 seconds to under 500ms

**Breaking it down:**
- Situation: Mobile app needed notifications
- Task: Build a real-time system
- Action: Used WebSockets and Redis, designed the architecture
- Result: Instant alerts, faster delivery
- Quantification: 850K users, 30s → 500ms

sections.heading: Finding Numbers When You Don't Have Them
sections.content:
"But I don't have access to metrics!" I hear this all the time. Here's how to find or estimate numbers:

**1. Ask your manager or team lead**
They often have access to dashboards and metrics you don't see.

**2. Check internal tools**
Datadog, New Relic, Google Analytics, Mixpanel—these tools often have historical data.

**3. Make reasonable estimates**
- "Approximately 500 users" is better than no number
- "Reduced build time by ~40%" is still impactful
- Use ranges: "Processed 100K-150K transactions daily"

**4. Calculate from what you know**
If your company has 10,000 employees and you built an internal tool used company-wide, you can say "deployed to 10,000 employees."

**5. Measure going forward**
Start documenting your impact now. Keep a "brag document" of wins, metrics, and achievements.

**6. Use comparisons**
"Reduced deployment time from 2 hours to 15 minutes" doesn't need exact percentages—the comparison speaks for itself.

sections.heading: Quantified Bullet Examples by Role
sections.content:
Here are examples for different tech roles:

**Software Engineer:**
- Reduced database query time by 80% through indexing optimization, improving API response times for 2M daily requests
- Built CI/CD pipeline that decreased deployment time from 45 minutes to 8 minutes, enabling 3x more frequent releases
- Refactored legacy authentication system, eliminating 40+ security vulnerabilities identified in penetration testing

**Frontend Developer:**
- Improved Core Web Vitals scores by 35%, increasing organic search traffic by 18%
- Built component library used by 12 teams, reducing UI development time by 40%
- Implemented lazy loading and code splitting, reducing initial bundle size from 2.1MB to 380KB

**Data Engineer:**
- Designed data pipeline processing 15TB daily with 99.9% reliability
- Reduced ETL job runtime from 6 hours to 45 minutes through parallel processing optimization
- Built real-time analytics dashboard serving 200+ internal stakeholders

**DevOps/SRE:**
- Achieved 99.99% uptime for production systems serving 5M monthly active users
- Reduced AWS costs by $180K annually through right-sizing and reserved instance optimization
- Decreased mean time to recovery (MTTR) from 45 minutes to 8 minutes through improved monitoring

sections.heading: Avoiding Common Pitfalls
sections.content:
Numbers are powerful, but they can backfire if used incorrectly:

**1. Don't make up numbers**
Estimates are fine if clearly approximate. Fabricated numbers will unravel in interviews.

**2. Don't use vanity metrics**
"Wrote 10,000 lines of code" means nothing. Lines of code isn't a measure of value.

**3. Don't forget context**
"Reduced errors by 50%" could mean going from 2 errors to 1, or 2 million to 1 million. Scale matters.

**4. Don't over-optimize for numbers**
Every bullet doesn't need a metric. The most impactful 2-3 achievements per role should be quantified.

**5. Don't take solo credit for team achievements**
Use "contributed to" or "as part of a 5-person team" for collaborative work.

**The golden rule:** If an interviewer asks "How do you know that number?" you should have a credible answer.

resources.title: Brag Document Template
resources.description: How to keep a record of your achievements for performance reviews and resumes

resources.title: STAR Method Guide
resources.description: Framework for structuring your achievement stories

resources.title: Action Verbs for Resumes
resources.description: Comprehensive list of powerful action verbs for professional resumes

keyTakeaways: Numbers provide proof—'improved performance by 65%' beats 'improved performance'
Quantify performance, scale, business impact, and process improvements
Use the STAR-Q method: Situation, Task, Action, Result, Quantification
Estimate when you don't have exact numbers, but be prepared to explain your methodology
Keep a 'brag document' to track achievements and metrics throughout your career

winning-resume-examples.title: Winning Resume Examples
winning-resume-examples.intro: Theory is great, but seeing real examples is better. In this lesson, we'll break down actual resumes that landed interviews at top tech companies. You'll see exactly what works, why it works, and how to apply these patterns to your own resume.

sections.heading: Example 1: Junior Software Engineer
sections.content:
This resume helped a bootcamp graduate land their first role at a Series B startup.

```
SARAH CHEN
sarah.chen@email.com | (555) 123-4567 | linkedin.com/in/sarahchen | github.com/sarahchen
San Francisco, CA

SOFTWARE ENGINEER
Full-stack developer with expertise in React, Node.js, and PostgreSQL.
Passionate about building accessible, user-centered applications.

SKILLS

Languages: JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, SQL, HTML/CSS
Frameworks: React, Next.js, Node.js, Express, React Native
Databases: PostgreSQL, MongoDB, Redis, Firebase
Tools: Git, Docker, AWS (EC2, S3, RDS), Figma, Jest

PROJECTS

TaskFlow | React, Node.js, PostgreSQL, Socket.io | taskflow-app.com
• Built a real-time project management app with drag-and-drop Kanban boards
• Implemented WebSocket connections for live collaboration between team members
• Deployed on AWS with Docker, achieving 99.5% uptime over 3 months
• 200+ active users managing 1,500+ tasks monthly

WeatherWise | React Native, OpenWeather API, Firebase
• Developed cross-platform mobile app providing hyperlocal weather forecasts
• Integrated push notifications for severe weather alerts
• 4.5-star rating on App Store with 500+ downloads

Accessibility Auditor | Python, Selenium, BeautifulSoup | github.com/sarahchen/a11y-audit
• Created CLI tool that scans websites for WCAG 2.1 compliance issues
• Generates detailed reports with remediation suggestions
• Used by 3 local nonprofits to improve their web accessibility

EXPERIENCE

Freelance Web Developer | Jan 2026 – Present
• Built custom websites for 5 small business clients using React and Next.js
• Reduced client's page load time by 60% through image optimization and lazy loading
• Implemented SEO best practices, increasing organic traffic by 40% for one client

Customer Success Manager | TechCorp Inc. | 2021 – 2023
• Managed relationships with 50+ enterprise accounts ($2M+ ARR)
• Collaborated with engineering team to prioritize feature requests
• Created technical documentation that reduced support tickets by 25%

EDUCATION

Software Engineering Certificate | App Academy | 2023
• 1,000+ hours of full-stack web development training
• Capstone project selected for demo day presentation

B.A. Communications | UC Berkeley | 2020
```

**Why this works:**
- Skills section immediately shows technical capabilities
- Projects section demonstrates real-world application
- Each project has metrics and real-world impact
- Previous non-tech role is framed with transferable skills

sections.heading: Example 2: Mid-Level Backend Engineer
sections.content:
This resume helped a 4-year engineer land a senior role at a FAANG company.

```
MARCUS JOHNSON
marcus.johnson@email.com | linkedin.com/in/marcusjohnson | github.com/mjohnson
Seattle, WA

SENIOR SOFTWARE ENGINEER
Backend engineer specializing in distributed systems and API design.
5 years building scalable services handling millions of daily requests.

SKILLS

Languages: Python, Go, Java, SQL
Frameworks: Django, FastAPI, gRPC, GraphQL
Infrastructure: AWS (ECS, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS), Kubernetes, Terraform
Data: PostgreSQL, Redis, Kafka, Elasticsearch, Spark
Practices: CI/CD, Infrastructure as Code, Observability (Datadog, PagerDuty)

EXPERIENCE

Software Engineer II | CloudScale Inc. | 2022 – Present
• Architected microservices migration that improved system reliability from 99.5% to 99.99% uptime
• Reduced API latency by 65% (from 340ms to 120ms) by implementing Redis caching and query optimization
• Led design and implementation of event-driven architecture processing 2M+ events daily
• Mentored 3 junior engineers through code reviews and pair programming sessions
• Introduced comprehensive API documentation, reducing integration time for partner teams by 40%

Software Engineer | DataStream Analytics | 2020 – 2022
• Built real-time data pipeline processing 500GB daily using Apache Kafka and Spark
• Designed REST APIs serving 50+ internal and external clients
• Implemented automated testing suite increasing code coverage from 45% to 85%
• Reduced infrastructure costs by $120K annually through AWS resource optimization
• On-call rotation: maintained <15 minute response time for P1 incidents

Junior Software Engineer | StartupXYZ | 2019 – 2020
• Developed core features for B2B SaaS platform serving 200+ enterprise customers
• Built webhook system enabling real-time integrations with customer systems
• Collaborated with product team to ship 12 features over 18 months

EDUCATION

B.S. Computer Science | University of Washington | 2019
• Relevant coursework: Distributed Systems, Database Systems, Algorithms
• Teaching Assistant for Introduction to Programming (CSE 142)
```

**Why this works:**
- Skills section upfront for quick technical screening
- Strong quantified achievements at every role
- Shows progression from junior to senior-level work
- Demonstrates both technical depth and leadership (mentoring)

sections.heading: Example 3: Career Changer (Teacher to Developer)
sections.content:
This resume helped a former high school teacher land a frontend developer role.

```
EMILY RODRIGUEZ
emily.rodriguez@email.com | linkedin.com/in/emilyrodriguez | emilyrodriguez.dev
Austin, TX

FRONTEND DEVELOPER
Former educator turned developer. I bring the same patience, clarity, and
user-empathy that made me an effective teacher to building intuitive interfaces.

SKILLS

Core: JavaScript, TypeScript, HTML5, CSS3/Sass
Frameworks: React, Next.js, Vue.js
Styling: Tailwind CSS, Styled Components, CSS Modules
Testing: Jest, React Testing Library, Cypress
Tools: Git, Figma, Webpack, Vite

TECHNICAL PROJECTS

LearnPath | React, TypeScript, Firebase, Tailwind CSS | learnpath.app
• Built an interactive learning platform helping students track educational goals
• Implemented spaced repetition algorithm improving user retention by 35%
• Designed mobile-first responsive UI serving 400+ monthly active users
• Integrated with Google Calendar API for study session scheduling

Classroom Dashboard | Next.js, Chart.js, Supabase
• Created analytics dashboard for teachers to visualize student progress
• Built real-time updates using Supabase subscriptions
• Reduced time teachers spend on progress reports by 50% (based on user feedback)

Accessible Component Library | React, Storybook, Jest
• Developed 15+ reusable UI components following WCAG 2.1 AA standards
• Published as npm package with 200+ weekly downloads
• Comprehensive documentation with interactive examples

OPEN SOURCE CONTRIBUTIONS

• freeCodeCamp: Fixed 3 accessibility issues in the learning platform
• MDN Web Docs: Contributed corrections to JavaScript documentation
• React-A11y: Added keyboard navigation support to dropdown component

PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE

High School Math Teacher | Austin ISD | 2018 – 2023
• Taught 150+ students annually, consistently achieving 90%+ pass rates
• Developed interactive web-based learning tools using basic JavaScript
• Led professional development workshops on educational technology
• Collaborated with cross-functional teams (counselors, admin, parents)

EDUCATION & CERTIFICATIONS

Frontend Development Certificate | freeCodeCamp | 2023
React Developer Certification | Meta | 2023
M.Ed. Curriculum & Instruction | UT Austin | 2018
B.S. Mathematics | Texas State University | 2016
```

**Why this works:**
- Skills section immediately establishes technical credibility
- Summary directly addresses the career change with a compelling narrative
- Projects demonstrate real-world application and user impact
- Open source contributions show community involvement and initiative

sections.heading: Example 4: Senior/Staff Level Engineer
sections.content:
This resume helped a senior engineer land a Staff Engineer role at a public tech company.

```
DAVID PARK
david.park@email.com | linkedin.com/in/davidpark | davidpark.dev
New York, NY

STAFF SOFTWARE ENGINEER
Technical leader with 8+ years building high-scale distributed systems.
Track record of leading cross-functional initiatives and mentoring engineering teams.

TECHNICAL SKILLS

Languages: Java, Python, Go, Scala
Distributed Systems: Kafka, Redis, Cassandra, DynamoDB, gRPC
Infrastructure: Kubernetes, Terraform, AWS, GCP
Practices: System Design, Technical Leadership, Architecture Reviews

EXPERIENCE

Senior Software Engineer → Tech Lead | FinanceApp Inc. | 2021 – Present
• Led architecture redesign reducing payment processing latency from 2s to 200ms (10x improvement)
• Designed and implemented fraud detection system preventing $5M+ in fraudulent transactions annually
• Drove adoption of event sourcing pattern across 4 teams, improving system auditability
• Established engineering RFC process, improving cross-team alignment on technical decisions
• Grew team from 4 to 12 engineers while maintaining velocity and code quality
• Promoted from Senior to Tech Lead within 18 months based on technical impact

Senior Software Engineer | E-commerce Giant | 2018 – 2021
• Built inventory management system handling 10M+ SKUs across 500 warehouses
• Reduced order fulfillment errors by 60% through real-time inventory synchronization
• Led migration from monolith to microservices for checkout flow (zero-downtime, 6-month project)
• Mentored 5 engineers, 2 of whom were promoted to senior level
• Authored internal engineering blog posts with 10K+ views on system design topics

Software Engineer | AdTech Startup | 2015 – 2018
• Built real-time bidding platform processing 500K requests/second
• Implemented A/B testing framework used by 20+ product teams
• Contributed to company acquisition by major ad network ($50M exit)

EDUCATION

M.S. Computer Science | Stanford University | 2015
• Focus: Distributed Systems
• Thesis: "Consistency Models in Geo-Distributed Databases"

B.S. Computer Science | UC San Diego | 2013

SPEAKING & WRITING

• "Scaling Payment Systems" – QCon San Francisco 2023
• "Event Sourcing in Practice" – Company Engineering Blog (15K views)
• Internal Tech Talks: System Design Interview Prep (monthly series)
```

**Why this works:**
- Skills section showcases architecture-level expertise upfront
- Shows clear career progression with promotion
- Emphasizes leadership and cross-functional impact
- Speaking and writing demonstrate thought leadership

sections.heading: Example 5: Data/ML Engineer
sections.content:
This resume helped a data engineer transition into a machine learning engineering role.

```
AISHA PATEL
aisha.patel@email.com | linkedin.com/in/aishapatel | github.com/aishapatel
San Jose, CA

MACHINE LEARNING ENGINEER
Data engineer transitioning to ML. 4 years building data pipelines,
now focused on productionizing ML models at scale.

SKILLS

ML/AI: PyTorch, TensorFlow, scikit-learn, Hugging Face, MLflow
Data: Python, SQL, Spark, Airflow, dbt
Infrastructure: AWS (SageMaker, EMR, Glue), Kubernetes, Docker
ML Ops: Feature Stores, Model Monitoring, A/B Testing

EXPERIENCE

Senior Data Engineer | HealthTech Corp | 2021 – Present
• Built ML feature store serving 50+ models with sub-100ms latency
• Designed real-time inference pipeline processing 1M predictions/day for patient risk scoring
• Reduced model deployment time from 2 weeks to 2 days through MLOps automation
• Collaborated with data scientists to productionize 8 ML models in past year
• Implemented A/B testing framework for ML models, enabling data-driven iteration

Data Engineer | Analytics Co. | 2019 – 2021
• Built ETL pipelines processing 5TB daily for business intelligence platform
• Created data quality monitoring system reducing data incidents by 70%
• Designed dimensional data model supporting 100+ analysts and 500+ dashboards
• Migrated data warehouse from on-prem to Snowflake, reducing query times by 80%

PROJECTS

Real-Time Recommendation Engine | Personal Project
• Built collaborative filtering system using PyTorch serving 10K+ recommendations/day
• Deployed on AWS SageMaker with automated retraining pipeline
• Achieved 25% improvement in click-through rate vs. baseline

Sentiment Analysis API | GitHub (500+ stars)
• Open-source NLP API for real-time sentiment analysis
• Fine-tuned BERT model achieving 92% accuracy on custom dataset
• Containerized with Docker, deployed on Kubernetes

EDUCATION & CERTIFICATIONS

M.S. Data Science | Georgia Tech (Online) | 2023
• Specialization: Machine Learning
• Capstone: "Predictive Maintenance Using Sensor Data"

AWS Machine Learning Specialty | 2023
B.S. Statistics | UCLA | 2019
```

**Why this works:**
- Skills section leads with ML tools to establish new direction
- Summary addresses the transition directly
- Current role bullets emphasize ML-adjacent work
- Projects demonstrate hands-on ML skills

sections.heading: Key Patterns Across All Examples
sections.content:
Looking at these resumes, several patterns emerge:

**1. Skills come right after the summary**
Recruiters scan for technical keywords first. Putting skills near the top ensures they see your tech stack immediately.

**2. Every bullet has impact**
No bullet just describes a task. Each one shows what was built AND what result it achieved.

**3. Numbers are specific**
Not "improved performance" but "reduced latency from 340ms to 120ms." Specific numbers are more credible.

**4. Format is consistent**
Same structure throughout: Company | Title | Dates, followed by bullets. Easy to scan.

**5. Skills match the role**
A frontend developer lists React prominently. A backend engineer leads with distributed systems. Tailor your skills section.

**6. One page (or just barely two)**
Even the Staff Engineer example fits on one page. Edit ruthlessly.

**7. No fluff**
- No "References available upon request"
- No objective statements
- No obvious skills ("Microsoft Word")
- No paragraphs—just scannable bullets

**Use these as templates, not copies.** Adapt the structure and patterns to tell your own story.

resources.title: Jake's Resume Template
resources.description: The clean LaTeX template used in many of these examples

resources.title: Tech Resume Templates
resources.description: Professional templates with ATS-friendly formatting

resources.title: r/EngineeringResumes
resources.description: Active community for resume feedback and real examples

resources.title: Levels.fyi Resume Examples
resources.description: Resume tips from the tech compensation experts

keyTakeaways: Lead with your most relevant experience—projects for career changers, work history for experienced engineers
Every bullet should show both what you did AND the measurable impact
Use specific numbers: '340ms to 120ms' is more credible than 'improved performance'
Keep formatting consistent and scannable—same structure for each role
Tailor your skills section to match the role you're applying for
One page is ideal; only go to two if you have 10+ years of highly relevant experience

linkedin-profile-optimization.title: LinkedIn Profile Optimization
linkedin-profile-optimization.intro: Your LinkedIn profile isn't just an online resume—it's a 24/7 marketing machine for your career. Recruiters spend an average of 6 seconds scanning profiles. In those 6 seconds, you need to communicate who you are, what you do, and why they should reach out.

sections.heading: The Power of LinkedIn in 2026
sections.content:
Let's be real about why LinkedIn matters:

**The numbers:**
- 95% of recruiters use LinkedIn to find candidates
- Users with complete profiles are 40x more likely to receive opportunities
- 87% of recruiters say LinkedIn is the most effective platform for vetting candidates

**What recruiters actually do:**
1. Search for keywords (job titles, skills, technologies)
2. Scan your headline and photo
3. Skim your About section
4. Check your experience for relevant roles
5. Look at your connections and endorsements
6. Send an InMail or move to the next profile

This entire process takes seconds. Your profile needs to pass the scan test before anyone reads the details.

> "LinkedIn isn't about being online—it's about being findable by the right people at the right time."

sections.heading: Profile Photo: Your First Impression
sections.content:
Your photo is the first thing people see. Profiles with photos get 21x more profile views and 36x more messages.

**The ideal LinkedIn photo:**
- Professional but approachable
- Clear, high-resolution (at least 400x400 pixels)
- Your face takes up 60-70% of the frame
- Good lighting (natural light is best)
- Simple, non-distracting background
- Recent (taken within the last 2-3 years)

**What to avoid:**
- Selfies or cropped group photos
- Beach photos or vacation shots
- Photos with sunglasses or hats
- Low resolution or blurry images
- Photos that don't look like you

**Pro tip:** Wear something you'd wear to a job interview. If you're in tech, business casual is usually perfect.

**Don't have a professional photo?**
Ask a friend with a decent phone camera. Stand near a window for natural light. Use Portrait mode. It doesn't need to be a professional headshot—it needs to look professional.

sections.heading: Banner Image: Prime Real Estate
sections.content:
The banner image is often overlooked, but it's prime real estate for personal branding.

**Options for your banner:**

1. **Personal brand statement**
Create a simple graphic with your tagline or areas of expertise.

2. **Company or conference photo**
Shows you're engaged in the tech community.

3. **Abstract tech imagery**
Code snippets, circuit boards, or other tech-related visuals.

4. **City skyline**
Works if you're highlighting your location as part of your brand.

**Tools to create banners:**
- Canva (free LinkedIn banner templates)
- Figma (if you want full control)
- Remove.bg (to extract yourself from backgrounds)

**Dimensions:** 1584 x 396 pixels (recommended by LinkedIn)

**If you're not sure:** A simple gradient with your name and title is better than the default gray background.

sections.heading: Building Your All-Star Profile
sections.content:
LinkedIn ranks profiles by completeness. An "All-Star" profile is 40x more likely to receive opportunities.

**All-Star checklist:**

✅ **Profile photo** — Professional, high-quality
✅ **Custom headline** — More than just your job title
✅ **Current position** — With description
✅ **Two past positions** — With descriptions
✅ **Education** — At least one entry
✅ **Skills** — Minimum of 5 skills
✅ **Industry and location** — Accurate and complete
✅ **Summary (About section)** — Written in first person
✅ **50+ connections** — Quality matters more than quantity

**Beyond All-Star:**
- Custom URL (linkedin.com/in/yourname)
- Featured section with projects or media
- Recommendations (given and received)
- Certifications
- Publications or articles
- Volunteer experience

sections.heading: SEO for Your Profile
sections.content:
LinkedIn is a search engine. Recruiters search for keywords, and if those words aren't in your profile, you won't appear in results.

**Where keywords matter most:**
1. **Headline** — Most heavily weighted in search
2. **About section** — Second most important
3. **Job titles** — Use industry-standard titles
4. **Skills section** — Direct keyword matching
5. **Experience descriptions** — Natural keyword inclusion

**Keyword strategy:**

1. Make a list of technologies, tools, and skills you want to be found for
2. Include variations ("JavaScript" and "JS," "Amazon Web Services" and "AWS")
3. Use the actual terms from job descriptions you're interested in
4. Include both technical and role-based keywords

**Example keywords for a full-stack developer:**
JavaScript, TypeScript, React, Node.js, Python, PostgreSQL, MongoDB, AWS, Docker, Kubernetes, REST APIs, GraphQL, Agile, CI/CD, Full-Stack Developer, Software Engineer

**Don't keyword stuff.** Natural language with strategic keyword inclusion is the goal.

sections.heading: Activity and Engagement
sections.content:
A profile isn't enough—LinkedIn rewards activity. Active users appear higher in search results and recruiter feeds.

**Weekly activity goals:**
- Post or share something 1-2 times per week
- Comment meaningfully on 3-5 posts
- React to relevant content daily
- Engage with your network's posts

**What to post:**
- Lessons learned from projects
- Industry news with your take
- Career milestones (new job, certification, promotion)
- Technical tutorials or tips
- Thoughtful comments on trends

**Engagement quality > quantity:**
A thoughtful comment on a popular post can be more valuable than your own post. "Great point about microservices architecture. In my experience at [Company], we found that starting with a monolith and extracting services later reduced complexity significantly."

**The compound effect:**
Consistent activity builds visibility over time. Recruiters notice people who appear in their feed regularly.

resources.description: Free templates for creating professional LinkedIn banners

resources.description: Technical blog with insights into how LinkedIn surfaces content

keyTakeaways: Recruiters spend 6 seconds scanning profiles—optimize for the scan
A professional photo increases profile views by 21x
Achieve All-Star status by completing all profile sections
Include keywords strategically in your headline, About section, and throughout your profile
Stay active with 1-2 posts per week and meaningful engagement on others' content

headline-and-about-section.title: Your Headline & About Section
headline-and-about-section.intro: Your headline is the most visible part of your LinkedIn profile—it shows up in searches, messages, comments, and post shares. Your About section is where you tell your story. Together, they determine whether someone clicks through to learn more about you.

sections.heading: The Headline: More Than Your Job Title
sections.content:
LinkedIn gives you 220 characters for your headline. Most people waste this space with just their job title. Don't be most people.

**The default headline problem:**
> Software Engineer at Tech Corp

This tells me nothing about what kind of engineer you are, what technologies you use, or what makes you unique.

**Headline formulas that work:**

**1. Role + Specialty + Key Technologies**
> Full-Stack Engineer | React, Node.js, AWS | Building scalable B2B SaaS

**2. Role + Value Proposition**
> Backend Engineer | Helping startups scale from 0 to millions of users

**3. Role + Technologies + What You're Looking For (if job searching)**
> Senior Data Engineer | Python, Spark, Snowflake | Open to new opportunities

**4. Role + Passion Area**
> iOS Developer | Making mobile banking feel human

**Pro tip:** If you're job searching, include "Open to Work" or "Seeking new opportunities" at the end. Yes, it's direct—that's the point.

sections.heading: Headline Optimization Tactics
sections.content:
Your headline is searchable. Recruiters search for job titles, technologies, and skills—and LinkedIn shows profiles that match.

**Keywords to include:**
- Your current (or target) job title
- Key technologies you work with
- Industry if relevant (FinTech, HealthTech, etc.)
- Seniority level if advantageous

**Headline structure:**
Primary Role | Key Skills/Technologies | Differentiator or CTA

**Examples by experience level:**

**Junior:**
> Software Engineer | JavaScript, React, Python | Building user-focused web applications

**Mid-level:**
> Senior Frontend Engineer | React, TypeScript, GraphQL | Performance optimization specialist

**Senior/Lead:**
> Engineering Manager | Leading distributed teams building ML infrastructure at scale

**Avoid:**
- Just your company name
- Buzzwords without substance ("ninja," "rockstar," "guru")
- Emojis (unless that's genuinely your brand)
- Abbreviations recruiters might not search for

sections.heading: The About Section: Tell Your Story
sections.content:
Your About section is 2,600 characters to make your case. Most people either leave it blank or write a boring third-person bio. Here's how to do better:

**First person is better:**
Write as yourself, not about yourself. "I build..." not "John is a software engineer who builds..."

**The hook matters:**
Only the first 3 lines show before "see more." Make them count.

**Structure that works:**

1. **Hook** (2-3 lines) — What you do, who you are, what drives you
2. **Story** (3-5 lines) — Your journey, how you got here
3. **What you bring** (3-5 lines) — Skills, expertise, achievements
4. **What you're looking for** (2-3 lines) — If relevant
5. **Call to action** (1-2 lines) — How to reach you

**Example About section:**

> I build products that make complex things simple.
>
> My journey into tech started when I automated my entire job at a law firm using Python scripts. That led to my first engineering role, and I've been hooked on solving problems with code ever since.
>
> Over the past 5 years, I've worked across the stack—from designing database schemas to building React interfaces to deploying services on AWS. Currently at [Company], I lead the team responsible for our payment processing system, handling $2M+ in daily transactions.
>
> What energizes me: Working with cross-functional teams, mentoring junior engineers, and finding the elegant solution to messy problems.
>
> I'm always open to connecting with other engineers, discussing interesting problems, or exploring new opportunities.
>
> Best way to reach me: [email] or send a connection request with a note.

sections.heading: Writing Your Hook
sections.content:
The first three lines of your About section are crucial—they appear before the "see more" link.

**Hook formulas:**

**The mission statement:**
> I help companies turn data into decisions. Over the past 7 years, I've built data platforms that have powered everything from fraud detection to personalized recommendations.

**The journey starter:**
> I went from teaching high school math to building machine learning models at a Fortune 500 company. Here's how I got here...

**The bold claim:**
> I've reduced deployment times by 90%, cut infrastructure costs by 60%, and helped teams ship features in days instead of months.

**The passion lead:**
> I believe every user deserves a fast, accessible, and beautiful experience. That belief drives every line of code I write.

**What to avoid:**
- Starting with "I am a..." (boring)
- Generic statements ("I'm passionate about technology")
- Listing skills (save that for the skills section)

Your hook should make someone want to click "see more."

sections.heading: Keywords in Your About Section
sections.content:
Your About section is searchable, so keywords matter here too—but don't sacrifice readability for keyword stuffing.

**Natural keyword integration:**

❌ **Keyword stuffing:**
> Python developer with Python experience in Python programming, Python Django, Python Flask, Python data science, Python machine learning.

✅ **Natural integration:**
> As a Python developer, I've built everything from Django web applications to machine learning pipelines using scikit-learn and TensorFlow. My experience spans backend API development, data engineering, and automation.

**Keyword categories to include:**
- Job titles (current and aspirational)
- Programming languages and frameworks
- Tools and platforms
- Methodologies (Agile, DevOps)
- Industries you've worked in

**Pro tip:** Include a "Skills" or "Technologies" line at the end of your About section:

> Technologies I work with: Python, TypeScript, React, PostgreSQL, AWS, Docker, Kubernetes

sections.heading: Common Mistakes to Fix
sections.content:
I've reviewed thousands of LinkedIn profiles. These mistakes are everywhere:

**1. Third person writing**
> "Jane is a passionate software engineer..." 

Use first person. It's more personable and authentic.

**2. Copy-pasting your resume**
Your About section isn't a place to list job responsibilities. Tell a story.

**3. Being too humble**
> "I'm just a developer who likes to code."

Own your expertise. False modesty doesn't land interviews.

**4. No call to action**
Tell people how to reach you or what you're open to.

**5. Outdated information**
> "Currently looking for junior developer roles" (while you're now a senior)

Update it regularly, especially when your situation changes.

**6. Blank or minimal**
An empty About section says you don't care about your professional presence. Even a few sentences is better than nothing.

**7. Too long**
If it's more than 6-8 paragraphs, you're losing people. Be concise.

resources.title: LinkedIn Headline Generator
resources.description: AI-powered tool to help craft compelling headlines

resources.title: LinkedIn Summary Examples
resources.description: Templates and examples for writing your About section

resources.title: LinkedIn Writing Tips
resources.description: Writing advice for creating a compelling LinkedIn presence

keyTakeaways: Use all 220 headline characters—include your role, key technologies, and differentiator
Write your About section in first person and start with a compelling hook
Only the first 3 lines show before 'see more'—make them count
Integrate keywords naturally throughout your About section without stuffing
Include a call to action telling people how to connect or what you're looking for

building-your-network.title: Building Your Network Strategically
building-your-network.intro: Your network is your net worth—especially in tech. A strong LinkedIn network opens doors to opportunities that never get posted publicly. But strategic networking isn't about collecting connections; it's about building genuine professional relationships.

sections.heading: The Hidden Job Market
sections.content:
Here's a truth most people don't realize: **70-80% of jobs are never publicly posted.** They're filled through referrals, internal promotions, and recruiters reaching out to candidates directly.

**How the hidden job market works:**
1. Company has an opening
2. Hiring manager asks team: "Know anyone good?"
3. Team refers people from their network
4. Role is filled before it hits job boards

Or:
1. Recruiter has a role to fill
2. Searches LinkedIn for keywords
3. Reaches out to matches
4. Best candidates get interviews

**What this means for you:**
If you're only applying to posted jobs, you're competing in a very crowded pool for a minority of opportunities. Building your network gets you access to the other 70-80%.

> "I got my last 3 jobs through LinkedIn. None of them were from applying to postings—they all came from people in my network."

sections.heading: Who to Connect With
sections.content:
Not all connections are equal. Be strategic about who you add to your network.

**High-value connections:**

1. **Recruiters in your field**
They're the ones with job opportunities. Technical recruiters, talent acquisition specialists, and recruiting managers.

2. **Engineers at companies you admire**
They can refer you and give you insight into the interview process.

3. **Hiring managers**
They're the decision-makers. Even if there's no current opening, they'll remember you when one appears.

4. **Peers at your level**
They'll move to new companies and can refer you. Your network grows as they grow.

5. **People you've actually worked with**
Former colleagues, classmates, hackathon teammates. These are your strongest connections.

6. **Thought leaders and content creators**
Engaging with their content increases your visibility.

**Who to skip:**
- Random connection requests with no context
- Obviously fake profiles
- People completely outside your industry (unless there's a specific reason)

sections.heading: The Art of the Connection Request
sections.content:
A personalized connection request is 10x more effective than the default "I'd like to add you to my professional network."

**Connection request formula:**
1. Context (how you found them or what you have in common)
2. Specific reason for connecting
3. What you appreciate about them (optional but effective)

**Examples:**

**To a recruiter:**
> Hi Sarah, I saw you recruit for engineering roles at [Company]. I'm a senior backend engineer with 5 years of Python/Django experience, and I'd love to be on your radar for future opportunities. Happy to connect!

**To an engineer at a target company:**
> Hi Mike, I came across your post about system design at scale—great insights on caching strategies. I'm exploring opportunities at [Company] and would love to connect and learn more about your experience there.

**To a former colleague:**
> Hey Jamie! It's been a while since we worked together at [Company]. I saw you're now at [New Company]—congrats! Would love to stay connected and catch up sometime.

**To a speaker/author:**
> Hi Dr. Chen, I really enjoyed your talk on MLOps at [Conference]. Your point about model versioning changed how I think about our deployment pipeline. Would love to connect!

**Keep it short—LinkedIn has a 300 character limit on connection requests.**

sections.heading: Nurturing Your Network
sections.content:
Connections are just the start. Relationships require maintenance.

**Weekly networking habits:**

1. **Engage with your feed (5-10 minutes/day)**
- Like posts from your connections
- Leave thoughtful comments (not just "Great post!")
- Share interesting content with your perspective added

2. **Reach out to dormant connections (1-2 per week)**
- Congratulate on job changes, promotions, or work anniversaries
- Share an article relevant to their interests
- Just say hello and ask how they're doing

3. **Help others (when you can)**
- Make introductions between people who should know each other
- Share job postings your network might be interested in
- Offer advice or feedback when asked

**The 5-minute favor:**
If someone asks for help and it takes less than 5 minutes, do it. Review their resume. Make an introduction. Share a resource. These small favors compound into strong relationships.

> "The best networkers I know are the most generous. They help freely without keeping score, and somehow opportunities always find them."

sections.heading: Leveraging Your Network for Job Hunting
sections.content:
When you're actively job searching, your network becomes your most powerful tool.

**Step 1: Announce your search (if comfortable)**
Post that you're looking for new opportunities. Be specific about what you want:

> I'm exploring new opportunities as a Senior Frontend Engineer, ideally at a company working on developer tools or B2B SaaS. If you know of any roles that might be a fit, I'd love to chat!

**Step 2: Reach out directly for referrals**
Don't be shy. Most companies have referral bonuses—your connections benefit from referring you.

> Hey Alex, I saw [Company] has a Senior Engineer opening. I'm really interested in the team's work on [specific product]. Would you be open to referring me? Happy to send over my resume and chat about my background.

**Step 3: Ask for introductions**
If you don't know anyone at a company, ask your network:

> Does anyone in my network work at [Company] or know someone who does? I'm interested in their [team/product] and would love an introduction.

**Step 4: Follow up on conversations**
After any networking conversation:
- Send a thank you message within 24 hours
- Connect on LinkedIn if you haven't
- Reference something specific from the conversation

**The numbers game:**
For every 10 people you reach out to, maybe 3-4 will respond. Of those, maybe 1-2 will lead to something actionable. Don't take silence personally—keep going.

sections.heading: Quality Over Quantity
sections.content:
LinkedIn tells you to get to 500+ connections. That number matters for visibility, but quality matters more for results.

**A strong network has:**
- People who actually know you and your work
- Diverse roles (engineers, managers, recruiters, founders)
- Diverse companies (startups, Big Tech, agencies)
- People at different career stages (junior to executive)

**Signs of a weak network:**
- Thousands of connections you've never interacted with
- No one from companies you want to work at
- Only people from your current/previous company
- No recruiters

**Quality check exercise:**
Go through your top 50 connections. For each one, ask:
- Would they respond if I messaged them?
- Would they refer me for a job?
- Could I ask them for career advice?

If the answer is "no" to all three for most connections, you need to invest more in building real relationships.

**Building quality connections:**
1. Have real conversations (coffee chats, video calls)
2. Provide value before asking for anything
3. Stay in touch consistently, not just when you need something
4. Be genuinely interested in others' careers

resources.title: LinkedIn Connection Limits
resources.description: Understanding LinkedIn's connection limits and best practices

resources.title: The 2-Hour Job Search
resources.description: Systematic approach to using your network for job searching

resources.title: Networking for Introverts
resources.description: Strategies for building a network authentically without forced interactions

keyTakeaways: 70-80% of jobs are filled through networks, not job postings
Prioritize connecting with recruiters, engineers at target companies, and hiring managers
Always send personalized connection requests with specific context
Nurture your network consistently—engage with content and reach out to dormant connections
When job hunting, leverage your network for referrals and introductions

cold-outreach-that-works.title: Cold Outreach That Gets Responses
cold-outreach-that-works.intro: Cold outreach has a bad reputation because most people do it badly. But done right, reaching out to strangers can land you interviews, mentors, and opportunities you'd never find otherwise. Here's how to send messages that actually get responses.

sections.heading: Why Cold Outreach Works
sections.content:
When you apply to a job posting, you're one of hundreds or thousands of applicants. When you reach out directly to someone, you're often the only person in their inbox asking for that specific thing.

**The math:**
- Job posting: 300+ applicants, 1% response rate
- Cold outreach: 20 messages, 20-30% response rate

Which gives you better odds?

**What cold outreach can get you:**
- Referrals to open positions
- Informational interviews
- Introductions to hiring managers
- Career advice and mentorship
- Insight into company culture and interview process

**The mindset shift:**
You're not bothering people—you're giving them an easy way to help someone. Most people want to help, especially if you make it easy for them.

> "Every senior engineer I know got their biggest breaks through outreach, not applications."

sections.heading: The Anatomy of a Great Message
sections.content:
A cold message needs to answer three questions in under 100 words:
1. Why are you reaching out to me specifically?
2. What do you want?
3. Why should I respond?

**The formula:**

```
[Personalized hook - why them]
[Brief intro - who you are]
[The ask - what you want]
[Make it easy - low commitment CTA]
```

**Example:**

> Hi Sarah,
>
> I saw your post about migrating to microservices at [Company]—the challenges you described around service discovery were exactly what my team is facing right now.
>
> I'm a backend engineer with 4 years of experience, currently exploring opportunities at [Company]. I'd love to hear about your experience on the infrastructure team—would you have 15 minutes for a quick call?
>
> Either way, thanks for sharing your knowledge publicly. It's been really helpful.
>
> Best,
> [Name]

**Why this works:**
- References something specific (not a template)
- Clear about who they are
- Specific ask (15-minute call)
- Low commitment (they can say no easily)
- Genuine appreciation

sections.heading: Finding the Right People to Reach Out To
sections.content:
Not everyone is equally likely to respond. Target strategically.

**High-response targets:**

1. **Recruiters actively hiring**
Search for "hiring" or "we're hiring" in LinkedIn posts. These people want to hear from candidates.

2. **People who post content**
If someone shares their knowledge publicly, they're generally open to conversations.

3. **Alumni from your school/bootcamp**
Shared background increases response rates significantly.

4. **People 1-2 levels above you**
Senior engineers and mid-level managers are more accessible than VPs and executives.

5. **Recent hires at target companies**
They remember what it's like to job search and are often happy to help.

**Finding them:**
- LinkedIn search with filters (current company, role, location)
- Company pages → "People" tab
- Alumni tool on LinkedIn
- Twitter/X for tech folks who share publicly
- Conference speaker lists and YouTube channels

sections.heading: The Follow-Up Strategy
sections.content:
Most people give up after one message. That's a mistake—80% of responses come after the first follow-up.

**Follow-up timeline:**
- First message: Day 0
- First follow-up: Day 3-5
- Second follow-up: Day 10-14
- Move on: After 2 follow-ups with no response

**Follow-up templates:**

**First follow-up (Day 3-5):**
> Hi Sarah, just wanted to bump this to the top of your inbox in case it got buried. I'd love to learn about your experience at [Company] if you have a few minutes this week. No worries if not—I know you're busy!

**Second follow-up (Day 10-14):**
> Hi Sarah, I know this might have slipped through. I'll leave you alone after this, but wanted to try one more time. If you're open to a quick 15-minute chat about [Company], I'd really appreciate it. If the timing isn't right, I completely understand.

**Rules for follow-ups:**
- Keep them short
- Don't be passive-aggressive
- Add value if possible (new reason to connect)
- Know when to stop (2 follow-ups max)

sections.heading: Handling Responses (and Rejections)
sections.content:
When someone responds, you need to be ready.

**If they say yes:**
1. Respond within 24 hours
2. Suggest 2-3 specific times that work for you
3. Keep it to 15-20 minutes as promised
4. Come prepared with questions
5. Send a thank-you note afterward

**Questions to ask in informational interviews:**
- What does a typical day look like on your team?
- What do you wish you knew before joining [Company]?
- What skills are most important for success in this role?
- What's the interview process like?
- Is there anyone else you think I should talk to?

**If they say no or don't respond:**
- Don't take it personally
- Thank them if they respond at all
- Move on—there are plenty of other people

**If they ask about your resume:**
- Have an updated resume ready to send immediately
- Include a brief note about what role you're interested in
- Follow up in a week if you don't hear back

> "Every 'no' gets you closer to a 'yes.' Rejection is just data—it means that person wasn't the right connection at this time."

sections.heading: Templates That Work
sections.content:
Use these as starting points, but always personalize.

**Template 1: Informational Interview Request**
> Hi [Name],
>
> I've been following [Company]'s work on [specific product/technology] and noticed you're on the [team name] team. I'm a [role] with experience in [relevant skills], and I'm exploring opportunities in this space.
>
> Would you be open to a 15-minute call to share your experience at [Company]? I'd love to learn about the team culture and what makes someone successful there.
>
> Thanks for considering!

**Template 2: Referral Request (to someone you've connected with)**
> Hi [Name],
>
> Thanks again for chatting with me last week about [Company]. I really appreciated your insights about [something specific they shared].
>
> I saw there's an open [role] that looks like a great fit for my background. Would you be comfortable submitting a referral for me? I can send over my resume and any details you need.
>
> Either way, thanks for being so helpful in my search!

**Template 3: Recruiter Outreach**
> Hi [Name],
>
> I saw you're hiring engineers at [Company]. I'm a [level] [role] with [X years] experience in [key technologies]. I'm particularly interested in [Company] because [specific reason].
>
> Would love to chat if you think there might be a fit. Here's my LinkedIn for reference: [link]
>
> Thanks!

**Template 4: Alumni Connection**
> Hi [Name],
>
> I noticed we're both [school/bootcamp] alumni! I'm currently a [role] looking to transition into [goal], and I saw you made a similar move a few years ago.
>
> Would you have 15 minutes to share how you navigated that transition? I'd really value any advice you might have.
>
> Go [mascot/team name]!

keyTakeaways: Cold outreach gets 20-30% response rates vs 1% for job applications
Great messages answer: why them, who you are, what you want, and make it easy to respond
Target people who post content, recent hires, and alumni—they're most likely to respond
Follow up twice before moving on—80% of responses come after the first follow-up
Always personalize templates with specific details about the person and their work

portfolio-and-projects.title: Showcasing Your Portfolio & Projects
portfolio-and-projects.intro: In tech, your portfolio speaks louder than your resume. Whether you're a junior developer breaking in or a senior engineer transitioning to a new field, projects demonstrate what you can actually build. Here's how to create a portfolio that opens doors.

sections.heading: Why Projects Matter More Than Ever
sections.content:
The job market is competitive. Everyone has a resume listing the same technologies. Projects are how you differentiate yourself.

**What projects prove:**
- You can ship working software
- You can solve real problems
- You have curiosity and initiative
- You can learn new technologies independently
- You care about craft

**Who benefits most from projects:**

**Career changers:** No relevant experience? Projects show you can do the work despite your background.

**Bootcamp grads:** A portfolio of projects bridges the gap between learning and professional experience.

**Junior developers:** Stand out from other juniors who only have tutorial projects.

**Senior developers:** Demonstrate expertise in technologies you've used professionally.

> "I've hired developers with no traditional experience because their GitHub showed me they could build things. Projects are proof."

sections.heading: What Makes a Project Stand Out
sections.content:
Not all projects are impressive. A to-do app tutorial isn't going to wow anyone. Here's what separates good projects from forgettable ones:

**Project quality checklist:**

✅ **Solves a real problem**
Did you build something you or others actually use? Or did you follow a tutorial step-by-step?

✅ **Goes beyond the tutorial**
If you started with a tutorial, how did you extend it? Add features? Use different technologies?

✅ **Shows technical depth**
Authentication, databases, APIs, deployment—your project should demonstrate real-world complexity.

✅ **Is deployed and accessible**
A recruiter should be able to click a link and see it working.

✅ **Has clean code**
Your GitHub repository is part of the project. Is the code organized? Is there a README?

✅ **Demonstrates recent work**
Projects from 3+ years ago with outdated technologies don't help. Keep your portfolio current.

**Project tiers:**

**Basic (everyone has these):** To-do list, calculator, portfolio website

**Intermediate:** CRUD app with authentication, API integration, data visualization

**Impressive:** Full-stack application with real users, open-source contribution, production-grade architecture

sections.heading: Project Ideas That Impress
sections.content:
Looking for project inspiration? Here are ideas by category:

**Personal tools you'll actually use:**
- Expense tracker that connects to your bank
- Job application tracker with analytics
- Personal dashboard aggregating your data (fitness, finance, etc.)
- Automated email/social media scheduler

**Problems in your previous industry:**
Did you work in healthcare, finance, retail? Build something that solves a problem you saw there.

**Open source contributions:**
Find an open-source project you use and contribute. Even documentation improvements count.

**Clone with a twist:**
- Build a simplified version of a complex app (Spotify, Notion, Figma)
- Add a unique feature the original doesn't have

**Technical showcases:**
- Real-time application (chat, collaboration)
- Data pipeline and visualization
- Machine learning model deployed as an API
- Browser extension
- CLI tool

**The best project is one you're excited about.** Passion shows in the code and in how you talk about it in interviews.

sections.heading: Building a Portfolio Website
sections.content:
Your portfolio website is your home base. It should showcase your best work and make it easy for recruiters to learn about you.

**Essential pages:**

1. **Home**
Your name, title, brief intro, and links to LinkedIn/GitHub.

2. **Projects**
Your best 3-5 projects with screenshots, descriptions, and links.

3. **About**
Your background, what you're looking for, and what makes you unique.

4. **Contact**
How to reach you (email, form, or LinkedIn).

**Project showcase format:**

For each project, include:
- Project name and one-line description
- Screenshot or demo GIF
- Technologies used
- Your role (if collaborative)
- Live link and GitHub link
- 2-3 bullet points on technical highlights or challenges

**Example project card:**

```
BudgetBuddy — Personal finance tracker with Plaid integration

[Screenshot]

Tech: React, Node.js, PostgreSQL, Plaid API

• Built full authentication system with OAuth 2.0
• Integrated bank data sync with automatic categorization
• Implemented responsive design serving 500+ monthly users

[Live Demo] [GitHub]
```

**Portfolio platforms:**
You can use website builders (Webflow, Squarespace) or build your own. For developers, building your own portfolio is itself a project.

sections.heading: GitHub as Your Portfolio
sections.content:
For many recruiters, your GitHub is your portfolio. Make it count.

**Optimizing your GitHub profile:**

1. **Profile README**
GitHub lets you create a special README on your profile. Use it to introduce yourself, highlight key projects, and show your tech stack.

2. **Pin your best repositories**
You can pin up to 6 repositories. Choose projects that:
- Have clean READMEs
- Demonstrate relevant technologies
- Are recent and maintained

3. **Green squares matter (somewhat)**
Regular commits show you're actively coding. But don't game it—quality matters more than frequency.

**Repository README template:**

```markdown
# Project Name

[One-line description of what it does]

[Screenshot or GIF]

## Features
- Feature 1
- Feature 2
- Feature 3

## Tech Stack
- Frontend: React, TypeScript
- Backend: Node.js, Express
- Database: PostgreSQL
- Deployment: AWS, Docker

## Getting Started
[Instructions to run locally]

## Live Demo
[Link to deployed version]

## Architecture
[Brief explanation or diagram of how it works]

## Lessons Learned
[What challenges you overcame]
```

**Write code like someone is watching—because they might be.**

sections.heading: Talking About Your Projects
sections.content:
Building is half the battle. You also need to talk about your projects in a way that impresses interviewers.

**The STAR method for projects:**

- **Situation:** What problem were you trying to solve?
- **Task:** What did you set out to build?
- **Action:** What technologies did you use and why? What was your approach?
- **Result:** What did you build? What metrics can you share?

**Common interview questions about projects:**

1. **"Tell me about a project you're proud of."**
Pick your best one. Explain the problem, your approach, technical challenges, and results.

2. **"Why did you choose [technology]?"**
Show you made thoughtful decisions, not just used what you knew.

3. **"What would you do differently?"**
Be honest. Every project has things you'd improve with more time or knowledge.

4. **"How did you handle [specific technical challenge]?"**
Go deep. Show you understand the trade-offs in your decisions.

5. **"Did you deploy it? How?"**
Deployed projects are more impressive. Know your infrastructure.

**Practice tip:**
Practice explaining your projects to non-technical friends. If they understand it, you can explain it to anyone.

keyTakeaways: Projects differentiate you from other candidates—they prove you can ship software
Great projects solve real problems, go beyond tutorials, and are deployed and accessible
Build things you're excited about—passion shows in interviews
Your GitHub profile is a portfolio—pin best repos and write excellent READMEs
Practice talking about your projects using the STAR method
